Home or away

17/07/2013

Image by

By undefined undefined

As you move forward in life and take steps towards independence, the life you leave behind will never be the same again. Whether that means your perspective has shifted and you no longer feel rooted in your family's home or whether change at 'home' has uprooted you without your consent, there's no doubt that you will be forced to look at your life in a new light. You will have to start making decisions which will ultimately determine where you spend your holidays, which friendships you will continue to pursue and which address you choose to use. It's strange how people pretend as though living in two places at once and ultimately living two separate lives simultaneously is normal, when really it's so counterintuitive. As a result, you're forced to compartmentalise your life, interests and relationships and it quickly becomes exhausting having to continually adjust to the home you've gone back to; whether that is your family's home or your home at university. Where ever you go, people are either wishing they're back at their other home or they don't find it unnerving living a double life. Something has got to give. You either have to make the decision to continue the juggling act or admit that you feel more at home in one of your homes, which will ultimately determine where you live and what you do with your future; whether that means going back to your hometown, staying in York or venturing further afield. University is a unique period in your life, which actually allows you more time in order to figure out where you stand on things and what you want to do in life. Being at university is freeing in many ways as you're not confined by the possible restrictions which feed into life at your family's home and there's virtually no element of people 'freeze framing' you as the person you used to be in high school. Others find security in being in their hometown with old school friends and familiar surroundings, even if only to momentarily escape from the responsibilities and pressures which university brings. I would have to say that in first year I found a combination of the two scenarios ringing true in my life and it was very much the way I viewed my two homes. However, as I've now come to the end of second year I'm finding that the latter has been pulled out from underneath me. Although I was already in the process of determining that I felt more at home in York (in deciding to stay and get a job over the summer), my parents have recently taken steps to ensure that I cannot back track in moving forward and cutting some ties with their home. Since Easter, they have decided they're moving abroad at the end of the calendar year and they have even moved house within the same city in the mean time - just to further ensure that the continuity which was in place in my life would no longer be present upon my return. Their move abroad will mean that half of third year will consist of my only base and actual home in the UK being in York, which has resulted in having to change my address on everything to York. Suddenly something which was only supposed to be temporary (like an address at uni) has become somewhat permanent in changing one small detail both mentally and on paper. Even though they've been talking about moving again for years, I didn't really think about how it would affect my future. By removing my 'other home' option, my parents kindly reminded me that I no longer have to follow them where ever they go, which is both a freeing and terrifying thought. The freedom that we feel at university shouldn't be temporary, it should be a taste of what life will be like beyond life at home in our family's home. There's nothing wrong with still finding a sense of belonging and sanctuary there, but if it prevents you from becoming independent and makes your temporary freedom at university remain truly temporary, then I think it's time to move on to your home that is away.
